tier.item: From: Handbook of Historical Linguistics (ed. by B. Joseph & R. Janda), Blackwell

igt.tag-types: L B B B M M B M B M B M M M B M B M B M B B M M M M B B G B T

tier.item: Indeed, the range of variability in the expression of the future tense in Medieval Greek texts i s
striking (and there are other formations that do not involve a form of thél that are not mentioned
here). The various types described here cooccur in texts, though there is a clear chronology to the
emergence of the different forms, as outlined by B nescu 1915.
Actually, hina in (7) is a bit anachronistic, since by the time it was introduced into the future tense
formation, it was probably already [na], and [na] developed from earlier hina by regular sound
changes; the representation of the Greek here is given in more of an approximation of the
pronunciation since in this form the future is now approaching Modern Greek.
From: Handbook of Historical Linguistics (ed. by B. Joseph & R. Janda), Blackwell
